content.text: Once upon a time, in a small village nestled between rolling green hills, there lived a little tailor.
He was not tall or strong like the blacksmith, nor was he rich like the merchant, but he was clever and quick with his hands.
Every day, he sat by his window, stitching and sewing clothes for the villagers.
His name was Hans, but everyone called him the Brave Little Tailor because of the bold words he had once embroidered on his belt: *"Seven at One Blow!"*  Now, how did Hans come to stitch those words?
One sunny morning, as he was eating his breakfast—a slice of bread with jam—he noticed a swarm of flies buzzing around his table.
With one swift motion, he grabbed a cloth and *swish!*—he struck the flies.
When he looked down, he saw seven flies lying still on the table.
"Seven at one blow!" he cried, delighted.
"What a mighty deed!" And so, he stitched the words onto his belt to remember his great victory.
That very day, as Hans walked through the village with his belt proudly displayed, the people whispered in awe.
"Did you hear? The tailor killed seven at one blow!" Soon, the news reached the king’s castle.
The king, who was always looking for brave heroes to serve him, sent for the little tailor at once.
When Hans arrived at the castle, the king looked him up and down and said, "I hear you are a great warrior.

If you can rid my kingdom of two troublesome giants who have been terrorizing the land, I will reward you with half my kingdom and my daughter’s hand in marriage."  Hans, though small, was not afraid.
"I will do it," he said boldly.
"But first, I must have a good night’s sleep." And with that, he curled up in a corner of the castle and fell fast asleep.
The next morning, the king’s servants led Hans into the dark, tangled forest where the giants lived.
As he walked, he spotted the two giants lying under a tree, snoring loudly. Hans had a clever plan.
He gathered a handful of pebbles and crept up to the giants.
Then, he tossed a pebble at the first giant’s chest.
The giant woke with a start and nudged his companion. "Why did you hit me?" he growled.
"I didn’t hit you!" the second giant roared.
"You must have dreamed it!"  Hans tossed another pebble, this time at the second giant. "Ow!
Stop hitting me!" the second giant bellowed, shoving the first.
Soon, the giants were fighting each other, rolling and punching and tearing up trees in their rage.
Hans watched from a safe distance, laughing to himself.
When the giants were too exhausted to lift their arms, Hans stepped forward. "Good morning, gentlemen!" he called cheerfully.
"I see you’ve been having a little disagreement."  The giants, panting and bruised, glared at him.
"Who are you, little man?" one grumbled. "I am the Brave Little Tailor," Hans said, puffing out his chest.
"And I have come to tell you that if you do not leave this kingdom at once, I will have to fight you both."  The giants burst into laughter.
"You? Fight us?" they roared. "You’re no bigger than a mouse!"  Hans did not flinch.
"Ah, but I am stronger than I look.
In fact, I once squeezed water from a stone!" And with that, he pulled out a lump of soft cheese from his pocket and squeezed it until drops of whey dripped out.
The giants stared in amazement. "Truly, you are strong," the first giant muttered.
"Perhaps we should leave this place."  And so, the giants fled the forest, never to return.
Hans returned to the castle, where the king was overjoyed. "You have done it!" the king cried.
"But before I give you my daughter’s hand, there is one more task.
A unicorn has been causing trouble in the royal meadow.
If you can capture it, the reward is yours."  Hans agreed at once.
The next morning, he set off for the meadow with a rope and an axe.
When he arrived, he saw the unicorn charging toward him, its horn gleaming in the sunlight.
Hans stood very still.
Just as the unicorn was about to gore him, he leaped aside and grabbed hold of a nearby tree.
The unicorn’s horn became stuck in the trunk, and no matter how hard it struggled, it could not free itself.
Hans quickly tied the unicorn’s legs with his rope.
Then, he chopped the tree with his axe until the unicorn’s horn came loose.
The creature, now tame, followed Hans back to the castle like a lamb. The king was astonished.
"You truly are the bravest man in the kingdom!" he declared.
And so, Hans married the princess and received half the kingdom.
But the princess, who was clever herself, soon discovered that Hans was not a mighty warrior but a clever little tailor.

Instead of being angry, she laughed and said, "Then you are the cleverest man in the kingdom, and that is even better."  And so, Hans and the princess lived happily ever after, ruling their kingdom with wisdom and kindness.

And whenever someone asked Hans how he had defeated the giants and the unicorn, he would smile and say, "It’s not the size of the man that matters, but the size of his courage—and a little bit of cleverness!"
